Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mantle Volatiles in an Emerging Ocean Basin: H2O, CO2, and He & Ar Isotopes in Basalts from the Gulf of Aden Spreading Center System
Award.AbstractNarration: Continental rifts and ocean spreading ridges are key places where volatile elements are exchanged between Earth's interior and its surface. Volatiles play a central role in the initiation of rifting/spreading, in volcanic evolution, and in associated geologic hazards. This research characterizes major volatile concentrations (H2O and CO2) and mantle source tracers (helium and argon isotopes) in magma erupted along the mid-ocean ridge in the Gulf of Aden in the Arabian Sea because this is a mid-ocean spreading center in its early stages of formation and evolution. The research also quantifies the flux of water coming from the mantle in the region. The Gulf of Aden is a unique locality for this work because it is a young ocean basin influenced by flow from the Afar mantle plume under the Horn of Africa. The plume affects the base of the Arabian lithosphere along the Red Sea and the western part of the Gulf of Aden; and its widespread influence is thought to result from the channeling of asthenospheric magma from the plume to the spreading center by rifts. However, the Afar Plume's apparent weaker penetration into the Gulf of Aden is not well understood and may be related to tectonic segmentation/discontinuities of the spreading ridge. The research will analyze submarine basalt glasses that were collected from previous oceanographic and sampling expeditions to the area for major element composition, volatile concentrations (CO2, H2O, Cl, F and S), and He and Ar isotopes. Initial results for Aden basalt glasses reveal a strong plume signal that may become rapidly attenuated with distance from the plume axis. Project goals are to determine how partial melting and degassing control mantle volatile signatures in young ocean spreading centers. Geochemical evidence (e.g., 3He/4He, 40Ar/36Ar, 4He/40Ar*, CO2/Nb, H2O/Ce) in about 40 basalt glasses from this region will be used to make this determination. Results of the study allow us to quantify variation in the volatile flux from the Afar plume and the upper mantle along the length of this emerging ocean basin between 44°E and 57°E. The results also provide a basic framework needed for geophysical and geodynamic models in terms of model input for regional and smaller scale variations in mantle composition, partial melting, and the heat and mass flux associated with the evolution from continental rifting to oceanic spreading. Broader impacts of the work include support of graduate and undergraduate students at two institutions, one in an EPSCoR state (Oklahoma), leverages existing samples collected with prior NSF support, and utilization of NSF-funded analytical facilities at Oregon State University and the University of Tulsa. Results will be described on institutional web pages as well as NSF-funded publically available data systems. Findings will also be incorporated into classes taught by the investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed at understanding the variation in volatile concentrations and isotopes in basalts erupted along a mid-ocean ridge during the early stages of ocean basin formation and evolution. We analyzed quenched submarine basalt glasses from the Gulf of Aden region (including Gulf of Tadjoura and Asal Rift basalts) for major volatiles (carbon dioxide and water) and helium isotope compositions. We also undertook studies of helium isotope variations in lavas and xenoliths from nearby areas on the Arabian Plate (Bir Ali volcanic field in Yemen and Harrat Hutaymah in Saudi Arabia; Fig. 1).

The Gulf of Aden is a young (<30 million year old) ocean basin at the boundary of the Arabian and Somalian tectonic plates, and is a site of mantle plume-spreading ridge interaction. Previous geochemical and geophysical work established that deep mantle upwelling is centered beneath a plate triple junction in Afar, and that portions of this upwelling mantle become laterally dispersed away from there. Helium isotopes along the West and East Sheba Ridges in the Gulf of Aden (Fig. 2) reveal a strong mantle plume signal similar to that observed in the Main Ethiopian Rift, with 3He/4He ranging up to 17 RA (RA is the 3He/4He ratio in air). This plume signal becomes rapidly attenuated by <400 km from the triple junction. Plume-derived 3He is more restricted in its spatial extent relative to other geochemical tracers, such as Pb isotopes and rare-earth elements, because helium is preferentially extracted from the mantle during vertical ascent of deep incipient melts within the central axis of the plume.

Eastward of the plume influence the Gulf of Aden shows very uniform 3He/4He (8.08±0.20 RA, n=22). This is the longest section of spreading ocean ridge characterized by such uniformity. The uniformity appears to arise from enhanced mixing, by small-scale mantle convection at the very slow spreading rates that are characteristic of the Gulf of Aden.

Helium isotope ratios in the Bir Ali xenoliths have a narrow range of values (7.2 to 7.9 RA) that are typical of the upper mantle away from the influence of mantle plumes. This is evidence that Afar plume activity had a very limited influence on the surrounding continental lithosphere. Helium isotope ratios in a variety of Harrat Hutaymah xenolith types are also homogeneous (mean 3He/4He of 7.54± 0.03 RA). This homogeneity is due to volatile equilibration between the xenoliths and fluids derived from their host magma prior to and during their transport to the surface. Notably, anhydrous spinel lherzolites have a lower value of 6.8±0.3 RA. Similar 3He/4He is commonly found in spinel lherzolites from the volcanic fields at Ithnayn and Al Birk, and from Zabargad Island in the Red Sea. These spinel lherzolites represent remnants of ancient lithosphere in the region that have not experienced the metasomatic overprinting. To date, elevated helium isotope ratios in the volcanic fields of western Saudi Arabia have only been observed at Rahat, a volcanic field situated above thinned lithosphere beneath the Makkah-Medinah-Nafud volcanic lineament. The helium isotope distribution in western Saudi Arabia is consistent with magma originating near the base of the continental lithosphere, and with the exception of Rahat any influence of the Afar mantle plume appears to be absent.

The project supported Ph.D. student Kevin Konrad. He gained valuable analytical experience working in the noble gas lab by analyzing xenoliths and lavas from volcanic regions in Saudi Arabia.  He published his first lead author paper during this project. The project also supported the principal investigator, David Graham, to refine analytical capabilities for helium and carbon dioxide trapped in small rock samples. The project supported an improved redesign of the high temperature vacuum furnace in the noble gas lab used for melting rocks and minerals. It also supported development of laser ablation analytical techniques for basalt glasses in the plasma spectrometery lab at OSU.

The isotope data obtained in this study are fundamental to understanding crustal accretion and volatile degassing along mid-ocean ridges. The observed variations in chemical and isotopic compositions along mid-ocean ridges are central in testing for the role of mantle plumes in driving the early rifting of continents, and in evaluating the accuracy of mantle convection models. The project supported further development of the state-of-the-art instrumentation in the noble gas and plasma spectrometry laboratories at Oregon State University, ensuring that they remain valuable sites for mentoring students and post-docs, and for fostering national and international collaborations.
